occurrences.line_text: Yet durst he not for very cowardize
Yet in his mind malitious and ingrate
Yet would not neare approch in daungers eye,
Which neuer yet they had approu'd in fight;
Yet nought abating of his former spight,
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
Which ye may see yet all about me steeme.
Yet rather counseld him contrarywize,
Yet deckt with wondrous giftes of natures grace,
Yet was she lou'd of many a worthy pere;
Yet not so freely, but that nathelesse
Yet had she not in all these two yeares space,
Saued but two, yet in two yeares before,
Yet would not let her lite, nor rest a little stead.
Hauing subdew'd, yet did to life restore,)
The greatest shame that euer eye yet saw?
Yet sau'd not so, but that the bloud it drew,
But yet the Prince so well enured was
And smote him on the knee, that neuer yet was bent.
It neuer yet was bent, ne bent it now,
It crackt throughout, yet did no bloud appeare;
Yet nathemore him suffred to arize;
Yet heauens them selues, that fauour feeble rights,
Yet is the bottle leake, and bag so torne,
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
Yet dwelling in her eye, to her appeard,
Yet neuer Turtle truer to his make,
Yet fearing death, and next to death the lacke
Yet she in so vnwomanly a mood,
Coridon enuies him, yet he
Yet seem'd the soyle both fayre and frutefull eft,
To whom Sir Calidore yet sweating comes,
Yet neither she for him, nor other none
Though meane her lot, yet higher did her mind ascend.
But after he had fed, yet did he stay,
Yet was not so, but as old stories tell
And all things therein meane, yet better so
That hauing small, yet doe I not complaine
Yet to occasion meanes, to worke his mind,
Yet she no whit his presents did regard,
Beholding all, yet of them vnespyde.
For that mishap, yet seeing him to mourne,
Yet was she certes but a countrey lasse,
Yet she all other countrey lasses farre did passe.
And liking in her yet vntamed heart procure.
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
Yet Calidore did not despise him quight,
Detaynd, yet Fortune not with all this wrong
Yet ceast he not to sew and all waies proue,
Yet could he not their iust demaund deny,
Yet like a Diamond of rich regard,
Yet holding fast twixt both his armes extended
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
They found that life did yet in her remaine:
And yet his feare did follow him behynd:
Whereat the knight amaz'd, yet did not rest,
Yet Calidore so well him wrought with meed,
That Pastorell yet liu'd, but all the rest
Yet making many a borde, and many a bay,
Whose course is often stayd, yet neuer is astray.
Though out of course, yet hath not bene mis-sayd,
Yet could not remedie her wretched case;
Yet left not quite, but drew a litle space
Yet did that auncient matrone all she might,
As yet not laced, nor her golden haire
Yet knowing not, what meant that sodaine thro,
That yond same is your daughter sure, which yet doth liue.
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
Were yrkesome to report; yet that foule Beast
Yet did he nought for all that him forbeare,
Yet greatly did the Beast repine at those
Yet durst he not draw backe; nor once withstand
Yet none of them could euer bring him into band.
Yf liuing man mote worthy be, to be her liefe.
So bene they gone yfeare, a wanton paire
With pleasaunce of the breathing fields yfed
O Goodly golden chaine, wherewith yfere
In this faire wize they traueild long yfere,
And Guyon his lost shield, they both yfere
So goodly all agreed, they forth yfere did ryde.
In fleshly lust were mingled both yfere,
That counsell pleased well; so all yfere
And swore, that he would lodge with them yfere,
So forth they both yfere make their progresse,
Next him went Griefe, and Fury matcht yfere;
Committed her, yfostered to bee,
A wicked Spright yfraught with fawning guile,
And round about yfretted all with gold,
Cymochles sword on Guyons shield yglaunst,
For his eye sight him failed long ygo,
With that great chaine, wherewith not long ygo
My liefe (sayd she) ye know, that long ygo,
Dead long ygoe I wote thou haddest bin,
To natiue crowne and kingdome late ygoe:
But when the Palmer, whom he long ygoe
For Ladies loue his mother long ygoe
And following Dee, which Britons long ygone
Hauing so peerelesse paragon ygot:
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
Did yield her comely person, to be at my call.
And mightie proud to humble weake does yield,
Where both do fight alike, to win or yield?
Thy guilty wrong, or else thee guilty yield.
Or that your prowesse can me yield reliefe:
And seem'd himselfe as conquered to yield.
For bloud can nought but sin, & wars but sorrowes yield.
To loose, ne yet the warlike pledge to yield,
Both daughter and eke kingdome, lo I yield to thee.
But yield his sence to be too blunt and bace,
Now forst to yield, now forcing to inuade,
Dye, or thy selfe my captiue yield for ay;
Yet yield he would not, nor his rancour slacke.
And to her captiue sonne yield his first libertee.
Loe there they be; to thee I yield them free.
Bid thee to them thy fruitlesse labours yield,
And yield him readie passage to that other part.
And then due praise, or due reproch them yield;
To yield wide way to his hart-thrilling brond;
And my trew liegeman yield thy selfe for ay,
Ne once did yield it respit day nor night,
And yield it those, that stouter could it wield:
So vnto wrong to yield my wrested right:
Which two did yield, before she did them smight.
And yield the pray of loue to lothsome death at last.
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
Against it strongly striue, and yield thee not,
Pitty our plaint, and yield vs meet reliefe.
Of froward fortune shall be forst to yield.
Shall yield him selfe his liegeman, and sweare fealty.
To yield himselfe vnto the mighty ill:
But yield her selfe to spoile of greedinesse.
I pardon yield, and with thy rudenesse beare;
Because to yield him loue she doth deny,
And bad the stubborne flames to yield him way:
Did yield himselfe right willing to prolong his date.
Yield you in liew of this your gratious deed?
And there arresting, readie way did yield,
And each to other seemd the victorie to yield.
He gan forthwith t'auale, and way vnto me yield.
And rather guilty chose him selfe to yield.
Did yield, she rather should with him remaine
To whom that day they should the girlond yield.
To stay her stroks, and he himselfe would yield:
Some place shall vs receiue, and harbour yield;
Dye rather, then doe ought, that mote dishonour yield.
And much to gaine, a litle for to yield;
Yielded by him, that held it forcibly.
But yielded passage to his cruell knife.
But yielded had to that same straunger knight:
Ne euer to them yielded foot of ground
Them yielded readie passage, and their rage surceast.
But trembling stood, and yielded him the pray;
And yieldes her to extremitie of time;
The yielding aire, which nigh too feeble found
Him stayd from yielding pitifull redresse;
It cut away vpon the yielding waue,
From yielding succour to that cursed Swaine,
Cadwallader not yielding to his ills,
Perceth the yielding ayre, and doth displace
Does seeke to perce: repining courage yields
And yields it selfe vnto the victours might;
But to the mighty victour yields a bounteous feast.
Seldome (said Guyon) yields to vertue aide,
Her to perswade, that stubborne fort to yilde:
Her therewith yirks, and still when she complaines,
To be the fairest wight, that liued yit;
From which I sprong, from me are hidden yit.
That may not be (said he) ne maist thou yit
Some such as in the world were neuer yit,
Whose like on earth was neuer framed yit,
In liuing brests, ykindled first aboue,
At last yledd with farre reported praise,
Why haue ye me alone thus long yleft?
And right and wrong ylike in equall ballaunce waide.
For light ylike is loth'd of them and thee,
Of yore, and many had ylike misled:
So both together ylike felly bent,
She held a great gold chaine ylincked well,
Ylinked arme in arme in louely wise,
Ioyous, to see his ymage in mine eye,
They bene ymet, both readie to affrap,
They bene ymet, and both their points arriued,
But in the middle way they were ymet
Like as a sort of hungry dogs ymet
He was ymett, who with vncomely shame
They bene ymett in middest of the plaine,
A flaming fire, ymixt with smouldry smoke,
And Ymner slew, or Logris miscreate;
The soring clouds into sad showres ymolt;
For golden Phoebus now ymounted hie,
Like to an Almond tree ymounted hye
For all he taught the tender ymp, was but
And thou faire ymp, sprong out from English race,
Faire ympe of Phoebus, and his aged bride,
Matchable either to that ympe of Troy,
The noble ympe of such new seruice fayne,
Faire ympes of beautie, whose bright shining beames
Amongst those famous ympes of Greece, did take
And hauing ympt the head to it agayne,
And daintie spices fetcht from furthest Ynd,
She wandred had from one to other Ynd,
Through boyling sands of Arabie and Ynde;
Till that his army dry-foot through them yod,
So long he yode, yet no aduenture found,
When as their Captaine heard, in haste he yode,
They courteous conge tooke, and forth together yode.
At last as through an open plaine they yode,
It was, with whom in company he yode,
That Paridell it was. Tho to him yode,
And both misplast; that when th'one forward yode,
So forth they yode, and forward softly paced,
Proud wemen, vaine, forgetfull of their yoke:
And made it beare the yoke of inquisition,
Of seruile yoke, that nobler harts repine.
Threatning to yoke them tow & tame their corage stout.
Till they him force the buxome yoke to beare:
Wyld beasts in yron yokes he would compell;
Therefore I will their sweatie yokes assoyle,
Our wearie yokes, to gather fresher sprights,
Vnfitly yokt together in one teeme,
Once to me yold, not to be yold againe:
Once to me yold, not to be yold againe:
So to her yold the flames, and did their force reuolt,
Emongst the shepheard swaynes, then wexeth wood & yond.
As Florimell fled from that Monster yond,
Good lucke presents you with yond louely mayd,
Will chalenge yond same other for my fee:
Clarin (sayd she) thou seest yond Fayry Knight,
Not farre from hence, vppon yond rocky hill,
Yond Lady and her Squire with foule despight
That yond same is your daughter sure, which yet doth liue.
Then cryde the Dwarfe, lo yonder is the same,
To yonder same Hierusalem do bend,
And pointing forth, lo yonder is (said she)
Loe yonder he, cryde Archimage alowd,
O stay thy hand, for yonder is no game
And now in shade he shrowded yonder lies.
For yonder comes the prowest knight aliue,
And keepe an euen course; for yonder way
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
Whom he hath left in yonder forrest wyld:
That yonder in that wastefull wildernesse
And iustifie my cause on yonder knight.
But yet he pricked ouer yonder plaine,
Whom he did ouerthrow by yonder foord,
The same is yonder Lady, whom high God did saue.
A thousand yong ones, which she dayly fed,
But in vaine sheows, that wont yongknights bewitch,
Of ancient Kings and Queenes, that had of yore
Into an Oxe he was transform'd of yore:
And noble minds of yore allyed were,
Which though he hath polluted oft of yore,
Then all his wars and spoiles, the which he did of yore.
Him Atin spying, knew right well of yore,
Though all the wealth, which is, or was of yore,
For that same knights owne sword this is of yore,
For well of yore he learned had to ride,
Or the Thessalian Tempe, where of yore
Shew'dst thou, then in this royall Maid of yore,
Were from him hidden, or vnknowne of yore.
Which Bladud made by Magick art of yore,
As it at first created was of yore.
To which sad louers were transformd of yore;
Great wreake to many errant knights of yore,
Proteus is Shepheard of the seas of yore,
For all that art he learned had of yore.
Of yore, and many had ylike misled:
Of him, who goodly learned had of yore
Phidias did make in Paphos Isle of yore,
But to the antique vse, which was of yore,
Hath now forgot, where he was plast of yore,
What was the poyse of euery part of yore:
For of the earth they formed were of yore;
As was the wont of warlike knights of yore,
Which warlike vses had deuiz'd of yore.
But that enuenimd sting, the which of yore,
A lawlesse people, Brigants hight of yore,
And after him Sir Lamoracke of yore,
And wonned there, where now Yorke people dwell;
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
I better wot then you, though now too late
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
Who see your vanquisht foes before you lye:
Well worthy be you of that Armorie,
Of a straunge man I can you tidings tell,
And shall you well reward to shew the place,
You, whom my hard auenging destinie
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
That for my sake vnknowne such griefe vnto you grew.
I deeme your loue, and hold me to you bound;
Crauing of you in pitty of my state,
Hauing both found a new friend you to aid,
And lost an old foe, that did you molest:
Least to you hap, that happened to me heare,
Are you in this misformed house to dwell?
That may restore you to your wonted well?
As you to leaue, that haue me loued still,
Then I leaue you, my liefe, yborne of heauenly berth.
And sooth to say, why I left you so long,
Haue vowd you to defend. Now then your plaint appease.
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
To you th'inheritance belongs by right
Of brothers prayse, to you eke longs his loue.
Be vnreueng'd, that calles to you aboue
I no whit reck, ne you the like need to reherce.
Or enimies powre hath now captiued you,
And with Sans-foyes dead dowry you endew.
Shall follow you. So passing forth she him obaid.
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
But wofull Ladie let me you intrete,
You to inquere the secrets of my griefe,
Then heare the storie sad, which I shall tell you briefe.
Can speake his prowesse, that did earst you beare,
And well could rule: now he hath left you heare,
Where haue you left your Lord, that could so well you tosse?
Where haue you left your Lord, that could so well you tosse?
But be of cheare, and comfort to you take:
Assure your selfe, I will you not forsake.
And you fresh bud of vertue springing fast,
Wherewith you to reward? Accept therefore
Haue made you maister of the field this day,
O heare, how piteous he to you for ayd does call.
On you hath fround, and pourd his influence bad,
Henceforth sir knight, take to you wonted strength,
Hath brought you hither into Faery land,
You to haue helpt I hold my selfe yet blest.
Deare Dame (quoth he) you sleeping sparkes awake,
And you, my Lord, the Patrone of my life,
For onely worthy you through prowes priefe
Then shall I you recount a ruefull cace,
Ne yet assur'd of life by you, Sir knight,
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
And you Sir knight, whose name mote I request,
Against my liking backe, to doe you grace:
By you, when ye arriue in that same place;
And you good Sir, I wote that of your toyle,
Iread you rest, and to your bowres recoyle.
Vnto you bring, to ease you of your misery.
Vnto you bring, to ease you of your misery.
The marriage to accomplish vowd betwixt you twain.
From knitting league with him, I you aread;
That you, most noble Sir, had present beene,
Great pittie is to see you thus dismaid,
For if he liue, that hath you doen despight,
He shall you doe due recompence againe,
The which good fortune doth to you present.
But now, faire Ladie, comfort to you make,
Or make you good amendment for the same:
So God ye speed, and send you good successe;
Ah deare Sir Guyon, well becommeth you,
Your court'sie takes on you anothers due offence.
Great cause, I weene, you guided, or some vncouth chaunce.
Where you he made the marke of his intent,
And said, Faire sonne, God giue you happie chance,
Ioy may you haue, and euerlasting fame,
Of late most hard atchieu'ment by you donne,
Where you a Saint with Saints your seat haue wonne:
But you, faire Sir, whose pageant next ensewes,
Hath with so huge misfortune you opprest?
Or die with you in sorrow, and partake your griefe.
Ne certes Sir striue you it to withstand,
And stird you vp to worke your wilfull smarts?
From which sad ruth does seeme you to restraine,
And giue you eke good helpe to their decay,
But mote I wisely you aduise to doon;
Thus to mislead me, whiles I you obaid:
Beteeme to you this sword, you to defend,
Beteeme to you this sword, you to defend,
But you, faire Sir, whose honorable sight
Sir knight, mote I of you this curt'sie read,
Great guerdon, well I wote, should you remaine,
But you, faire Sir, be not herewith dismaid,
I labour would to guide you through all Faery land.
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
Liues any, that you hath thus ill apaid?
Or doen you loue, or doen you lacke your will?
Or doen you loue, or doen you lacke your will?
What euer be the cause, it sure beseemes you ill.
You to molest, or other ill to feare
If it be I, of pardon I you pray;
I will, if please you it discure, assay,
To ease you of that ill, so wisely as I may.
You shamefast are, but Shamefastnesse it selfe is shee.
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
Your selfe you couet to see pictured,
And we your liege men faith vnto you plight.
Faire Sir, I let you weete, that from the howre
But mote I weet of you, right curteous knight,
You and your countrey both I wish welfare,
Ah, but if reason faire might you perswade,
For who with reason can you aye reproue,
No guilt in you, but in the tyranny of loue.
I weene, would you misseeme; for ye bene tall,
Will bring, and shortly make you a mayd Martiall.
Do one, or other good, I you most humbly pray.
So may ye gaine to you full great renowme,
At least eternall meede shall you abide.
As you in woods and wanton wildernesse
And ill becomes you with your loftie creasts,
Where you him lately left, in Mars his bed;
She you from death, you me from dread redeemed.
She you from death, you me from dread redeemed.
That shall I you recount (quoth he) ywis,
Of filthy wretch? well may shee you reproue
Faire Sir (quoth he) well may it you succeed,
Ne long shall Satyrane behind you stay,
Mote not mislike you also to abate
The which to let you weet, will further time require.
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
Old Mnemon. Therefore Sir, I greet you well
Your countrey kin, and you entirely pray
And you most noble Lord, that can and dare
Said Trompart, You that are the most opprest
You send, submit you to high prouidence,
You send, submit you to high prouidence,
Therefore, faire Sir, do comfort to you take,
Hath outrag'd you, and thrald your gentle make.
Deliuer her fro thence, or with her for you dy.
Aread what course of you is safest dempt,
Which earst to you I playnd: for neither may
Yield you in liew of this your gratious deed?
This, that in safety now I haue you seene,
Henceforth faire Lady comfort to you take,
Good lucke presents you with yond louely mayd,
Take then to you this Dame of mine (quoth hee)
Faire Sir, of friendship let me now you pray,
Your selfe for this, my selfe will for you fight,
For her that each of you alike doth loth,
Whilest both you here with many a cursed oth,
Since so good fortune doth to you present
So fayre a spoyle, to make you ioyous meriment?
This now be yours, God send you better gaine.
This happie day I haue to greete you well,
In which you safe I see, whom thousand late,
Long may you liue in health and happie state.
And you Sir Blandamour and Paridell,
That seeke perforce her from you both to take,
To you that ornament of hers pertaines,
That shall you win more glory, then ye here find gaines.
I me submit, and you of pardon pray,
That almost had against you trespassed this day.
But reade you Sir, sith ye my name haue hight,
What is your owne, that I mote you requite?
Me from discouering you my name aright:
Or doe you here within this forrest wonne,
And if to that auenge by you decreed
And if I hap to fayle, you shall recure my right.
I ioy to see you lout so low on ground,
And you Sir Artegall, the saluage knight,
Hath conquered you anew in second fight:
And you faire Ladie knight, my dearest Dame,
Mote I request you tydings of my loue,
My Amoret, sith you her freed fro thence,
I can not vnto you aread a right.
I vow, you dead or liuing not to leaue,
But what are you, whom like vnlucky lot
This mightie man (quoth he) whom you haue slaine,
Now were it not sir Scudamour to you,
Mote we entreat you, sith this gentle crew
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
And shame on you, ï¿½ men, which boast your strong
But this to you, ï¿½ Britons, most pertaines,
Ioy to you both, ye double noursery
Do you by duresse him compell thereto,
Gainst one that hath both wronged you, and vs:
So shall you by one gift saue all vs three aliue.
And for no cause, but as I shall you shew.
Deuided be betwixt you here in sight,
And you, Sir Knight, that loue so light esteeme,
Take here your owne, that doth you best beseeme,
If that (said Guyon) may you satisfie,
Lo there Sir Guyon, take to you the steed,
To you, that are our iudge of equity,
Two Ilands, which ye there before you see
My brother here declared hath to you:
And then you shall my sentence vnderstand.
By what good right doe you withhold this day?
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
By what right doe you claime to be your owne?
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
Or haue you lost your selfe, and your discretion,
Or haue ye yeelded you to proude oppression
Is falne on you, by heauens hard direction,
But tell, Sir Terpin, ne let you amate
I shortly will to you rehearse the same,
Therefore Sir Terpin from you lightly throw
And beare with you both wine and iuncates fit,
That this is things compacte betwixt you two,
I will not seeke the same from you to hide,
What May-game hath misfortune made of you?
As to haue robde you of that manly hew?
Saying, Sir Knight, of pardon I you pray,
That all vnweeting haue you wrong'd thus sore,
Or what so penaunce shall by you be red.
Towards my Ladies presence by you ment,
I would you guyde directly to the place.
Then turning vnto him; And you Sir knight
